image.altText: A woman speaking to a set of media microphones

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: PM slams 'Nazi rhetoric' as Thorpe reveals she's faced violent threats in Voice debate

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he is "not going to engage in a debate like that" in response to a question regarding allegations from Senator Lidia Thorpe that the prime minister and the AFP are not doing enough to protect her from the far right. "I would just say that it is appropriate that people be respectful in this debate," he said. "I will continue to conduct myself respectfully. "I will continue to 
campaign for a Yes vote in this referendum, as I've been doing." As we reported earlier, a video was published online in the last week by a masked neo Nazi, who referred to Senator Thorpe by name before burning the Aboriginal flag and performing a nazi salute. "I've seen the video 
that is referred to that is threatening towards Senator Thorpe and towards the government," Mr Albanese said. "The sort of Nazi rhetoric and comments that are in that video have no place in discourse in Australian political life."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Albanese says Nazi rhetoric has 'no place' in Australian  politics

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
says he is "not going to engage in a debate like that" in response to a question regarding allegations from
Senator Lidia Thorpe
that the prime minister and the
AFP
are not doing enough to protect her from the far right.
"I would just say that it is appropriate that people be respectful in this debate," he said.
"I will continue to conduct myself respectfully.

"I will continue to 
campaign for a Yes vote in this referendum, as I've been doing."
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaking in Brisbane.
(ABC News)
As we reported earlier, a video was published online in the last week by a masked neo Nazi, who referred to Senator Thorpe by name before burning the Aboriginal flag and performing a nazi salute.

"I've seen the video 
that is referred to that is threatening towards Senator Thorpe and towards the government," Mr Albanese said.
"The sort of Nazi rhetoric and comments that are in that video have no place in discourse in Australian political life."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Follow along on ABC News Channel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese is speaking now

children.content: Follow along on ABC News Channel.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Dana Morse Around 40 people gathered to support Senator Thorpe while she was making her statement addressing threats of racist violence and abuse against her. Senator Lidia Thorpe made allegations that the Prime Minister and the AFP is not doing enough to protect her from the far right. “His violent force that he has sent to protect me can’t even protect me, refuse to protect the black sovereign woman because the police are part of the problem in this country,” she said. “You want to paint me as an angry black woman, well you are about to see an angry black woman. “For months I wasn’t allowed to be in my own home, because people want to kill me out there,” she said. In a statement earlier today, Australian Federal Police said they were investigating the threats against Senator Thorpe, but would not discuss the protection arrangements in place for individuals. The Prime Minister is expected to speak in Brisbane shortly, where he will be asked about the matter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Thorpe makes allegations against PM and AFP saying they don't do enough to protect her

props.alt: A woman stands in front a group of micrphones.

children.content: Around 40 people gathered to hear Lidia Thorpe speak.
(ABC News: Courtney Withers)

is not doing enough to protect her from the far right.
“His violent force that he has sent to protect me can’t even protect me, refuse to protect the black sovereign woman because the police are part of the problem in this country,” she said.
“You want to paint me as an angry black woman, well you are about to see an angry black woman.
“For months I wasn’t allowed to be in my own home, because people want to kill me out there,” she said.
In a statement earlier today, Australian Federal Police said they were investigating the threats against Senator Thorpe, but would not discuss the protection arrangements in place for individuals.
The Prime Minister is expected to speak in Brisbane shortly, where he will be asked about the matter.

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe addresses the crowd in dark glasses.

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe says the Australian Federal Police (AFP) is failing to protect her after becoming the target of far-right extremist racist abuse.

title.children: Senator Lidia Thorpe accuses police of failing to protect her after Neo-Nazi racist abuse

image.altText: An aerial shot of brown murky flood waters surrounding several properties and a person walking through the water

items.synopsis: Days after being threatened by multiple, large bushfires, communities in the state's east are dealing with flooding as heavy rainfall continues feeding into river systems. Follow live.

title.children: Sandbagging underway, farmers move livestock as flood levels rise in Victoria's east

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The state's east and north-east are still dotted with dozens of warnings ranging from advice-level right up to the emergency warnings advising people that it is not safe to return to places like Newry, Tinamba and Tinamba West. People in those areas who have not followed advice and evacuated already are being urged to shelter in the highest location possible. A reminder of good sources of information to help keep you safe: The Vic Emergency app has all the latest warnings. The latest warnings are also available at the ABC Emergency website. Listen to ABC Local Radio for regular updates — find your local broadcaster here .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reminder to keep across the latest warnings

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan thanked the emergency service crews, including volunteers, who have been working in the state's east and north-east. "They started the week working on fires. Some of that fire activity continues and now in the later end of the week they are working on the flood response," she said. She said after flood levels peak, which is expected to occur around midday, teams would be better placed to assess any damage. "Teams will then be able to go in and assess the level of inundation, particularly in homes," she said. "They've not been able to get in and do that assessment yet because the floodwaters continue to rise and a number of roads remain closed in the local community." The premier said the release of water at Lake Glenmaggie and Lake Eildon had been discussed at an emergency meeting last night. She said nine people had spent the night at the relief centre at Sale, and that that personal hardship payments were available for those affected by the floods. "I want to thank local communities and local residents for heeding the warnings and making their decisions early as to how they can make themselves and their families safe in this emergency situation," Ms Allan said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Premier says flood damage will be assessed after levels  peak

children.content: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan thanked the emergency service crews, including volunteers, who have been working in the state's east and north-east.
"They started the week working on fires. Some of that fire activity continues and now in the later end of the week they are working on the flood response," she said.

children.content: She said after flood levels peak, which is expected to occur around midday, teams would be better placed to assess any damage.
"Teams will then be able to go in and assess the level of inundation, particularly in homes," she said.
"They've not been able to get in and do that assessment yet because the floodwaters continue to rise and a number of roads remain closed in the local community."
The premier said the release of water at Lake Glenmaggie and Lake Eildon had been discussed at an emergency meeting last night.
She said nine people had spent the night at the relief centre at Sale, and that that personal hardship payments were available for those affected by the floods.

"I want to thank local communities and local residents for heeding the warnings and making their decisions early as to how they can make themselves and their families safe in this emergency situation," Ms Allan said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Daniel Miles Southern Rural Water has responded to criticism it didn’t react quickly enough to forecast flooding in East Gippsland. Newry dairy farmer Steve Dwyer, whose property is impacted by the floods, told ABC Victorian Mornings that the peak water body should have released water from the Glenmaggie Weir earlier. “No attempt was made to drop the level of the ‘Maggie’ weir,” he says. The ABC understands water releases from Lake Glenmaggie reached 58,000 megalitres overnight. Southern Rural Water has defended its actions, stating it worked to the information available at the time. “We ran models before the events over the last couple of days and those models were based on the high end of the rainfall range in this catchment,” managing director Cameron Fitzgerald says. “The models aren't wrong, we use the best available information that we have. “And then of course, there are variations in what actually happens, where the rain falls in the particular catchment, and how that flows. He stopped short of apologising to residents, stating welfare’s been at the forefront of all decisions. “We have managed the dam in a way that has taken the peak off this flood,” Mr Fitzgerald says. “Unquestionably the dam being there has reduced the amount of flooding downstream.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Water authority defends Lake Glenmaggie management

children.content: Reporting by Daniel Miles
Southern Rural Water
has responded to criticism it didn’t react quickly enough to forecast flooding in East Gippsland.
Newry dairy farmer
Steve Dwyer
, whose property is impacted by the floods,
told ABC Victorian Mornings that the peak water body should have released water from the Glenmaggie Weir earlier.
“No attempt was made to drop the level of the ‘Maggie’ weir,” he says.
The ABC understands water releases from Lake Glenmaggie reached 58,000 megalitres overnight.
Southern Rural Water
has defended its actions, stating it worked to the information available at the time.
“We ran models before the events over the last couple of days and those models were based on the high end of the rainfall range in this catchment,” managing director
Cameron Fitzgerald
says.
“The models aren't wrong, we use the best available information that we have.
“And then of course, there are variations in what actually happens, where the rain falls in the particular catchment, and how that flows.
He stopped short of apologising to residents, stating welfare’s been at the forefront of all decisions.
“We have managed the dam in a way that has taken the peak off this flood,” Mr Fitzgerald says.
“Unquestionably the dam being there has reduced the amount of flooding downstream.”
Residents sandbagging at Tinamba.
(Supplied: Simon Johnson)

image.altText: a man infront of a granny flat

items.synopsis: New data released by CoreLogic shows the rental crisis is getting worse. With fewer affordable rentals on the market, more people are turning to granny flats, share houses and house-sitting to put a roof over their heads.

title.children: In the ongoing the rental crisis, Mike's best option is to call a granny flat home — and he's only in his 40s

items.synopsis: After Scott Morrison withdrew Australia from the United Nations-led Green Climate Fund in 2018, the federal government commits to rejoin the scheme, seeking a seat at the table to influence international climate projects.

title.children: Australia will re-join a global climate fund, five years after the Morrison government withdrew from it

items.synopsis: The ASX is gaining ground today, after a strong lead from Wall Street overnight. The latest trade surplus and household spending data sees one economist call a recession in Australia — follow live.

title.children: ASX gains ground in afternoon session, trade surplus and household spending data leads to economist calling a recession in Australia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fresh CoreLogic data shows it's getting harder to find a home to rent. The number of properties available is at a record low, with just 1.1 per cent of available properties vacant in September. The median weekly rent has gone up by 30.4 per cent in just three years, with people paying $137 more a week on average now than in July 2020. CoreLogic economist Eliza Owen says there is a shortfall of rental listings at a time when people are once again migrating to Australia in big numbers. "You've got real volatility with the private rental market and with the more vulnerable lower-income households." My colleague Emilia Terzon has written more about this, so I've linked it below. It has a really nifty interactive chart created by colleague Kate Ainsworth showing the least and most adorable suburbs to rent in Australia. It's a bit sobering.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The rental shortage is getting worse

featuredLink.title: In the ongoing the rental crisis, Mike's best option is to call a granny flat home — and he's only in his 40s

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian gold stocks are up as much as 2.1 per cent and set for their best day best day since August 30. The sub-index is tracing the global gains in gold prices ahead of US non-farm payrolls reports this week. The global spot gold price is up 0.3 per cent to $US1,825 an ounce. Newcrest Mining ($24.14 per share) jumped as much as 1.3% after announcing a a fully franked special dividend of US$1.10 a share. While Northern Star Resources ($10.60 per share) and Evolution Mining ($3.24 per share) are both on track for their best trading day since late August.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gold is glittering as stocks jump on rising prices

Newcrest Mining

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's been a bit of activity today which is driving positive growth on the ASX. The top 200 stocks are up 0.5 per cent and so is the broader All Ordinaries. ASX200 +0.51% to 6,925 All Ordinaries + 0.49% to 7,117 Looking at the sectors, eight of the 11 sectors are now in positive territory. Real Estate + 1.91% Telecommunications +1.29% Consumer staples +1.07% IT +1.0% Utilities + 0.88% Health care + 0.73% Financial + 0.71% Industrials +0.67% That leaves three in the red. Energy -1.06% Consumer -0.09% Materials -0.01%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX improves gains in afternoon trade

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks into microphones at a media conference standing in front of Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price.

items.synopsis: If the Voice isn't the solution, as Peter Dutton argues, what is? How will Australia tackle Indigenous disadvantage if the majority vote No? Given the polls all suggest a No vote is the most likely outcome, the answer is surprisingly unclear, writes David Speers.

title.children: Dutton has finally settled on an alternative solution to the Voice: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

items.synopsis: For the first time in seven decades, Australian currency will feature a new monarch. The new effigy of King Charles III faces the opposite direction on coins to his mother and also sees the king without a crown.

title.children: Australians haven't seen a king on their coins in 70 years. That changes today with the unveiling of this image
